Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether a subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation, as will allow corporate veil to be pierced under New Jersey law, courts apply the traditional common law factors, including the presence in both corporations of the same officers, directors, and shareholders, financial support of the subsidiary's operations by the parent, whether the property of the subsidiary is used by the parent corporation as its own, the failure of a subsidiary to observe the formal requirements attributable to its operation, and the involvement of the parent's corporate officers in the day-to-day business of the subsidiary.

Headnote: Even in the presence of corporate dominance, liability is imposed against parent under New Jersey law only when the parent has abused the privilege of incorporation by using the subsidiary to perpetrate a fraud or injustice, or otherwise to circumvent the law.

Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.

Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil will be pierced for jurisdictional purposes only when the subsidiary is acting as an agent for the parent, or the parent's control is so complete that the subsidiary is a mere department of the parent; jurisdiction over the foreign subsidiary will be found only when the activities of the parent show a disregard for the separate corporate existence of the subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors to aid in determining whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced, for jurisdictional purposes are: (1) common ownership, (2) financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent, (3) the degree to which the parent interferes in the selection of the subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formality, and (4) the degree of the parent's control over the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies; first factor, common ownership, is essential to the assertion of jurisdiction over a foreign related corporation, while the other three factors are "important."
Document Preview: Project director of electrical generating power plant built in El Salvador sued developers and El Salvador host company, seeking a declaratory judgment as to parties respective ownership...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced for jurisdictional purposes, financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent corporation exists where the parent provides no- or low-interest loans to the subsidiary or extends credit on terms not otherwise available, guarantees the subsidiary's obligations, or provides and pays for insurance coverage or other necessities on behalf of the subsidiary; courts also inquire whether the subsidiary retains its own profits or whether they are received by and reported on the financial statements of the parent but issuance of consolidated financial statements is not dispositive if the parent company is merely complying with SEC requirements.
Document Preview: Project director of electrical generating power plant built in El Salvador sued developers and El Salvador host company, seeking a declaratory judgment as to parties respective ownership...

Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In examining interference with executive personnel and failure to observe corporate formalities, courts attempting to determine whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced, for jurisdictional purposes, look to, inter alia, whether the parent shares officers with the subsidiary and shifts executives among its subsidiaries, whether the parent pays the executives' salaries, and whether the subsidiary holds separate meetings of its board of directors.

Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced for jurisdictional purposes, factor regarding the parent's degree of control over the marketing and operational policies of the subsidiary is satisfied where the parent's promotional materials or public documents hold out the subsidiary as a branch or division of the parent, or the parent determines the subsidiary's operational policies and strategy.

Title: Gardemal v. Westin Hotel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, degree of control necessary for finding parent corporation is alter ego of subsidiary is not mere majority or complete stock control but such domination of finances, policies and practices that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal; thus, one-hundred percent ownership and identity of directors and officers are, even together, an insufficient basis for applying the alter ego theory to pierce the corporate veil

Title: Conservatorship of Prom v. Sumitomo Rubber Industries, Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Factors considered in determining if parent corporation controls subsidiary to such an extent that separate corporate identity of subsidiary should be disregarded are (1) common stock ownership, (2) overlapping directors and officers, (3) combined use of corporate offices, (4) capitalization of subsidiary by parent, (5) financing of subsidiary by parent, (6) control of subsidiary's stock by parent, (7) use of the subsidiary's property by parent, (8) intercorporate loans, (9) parental incorporation of subsidiary, (10) consolidated tax returns, (11) independent decision making by subsidiary, (12) independent decision making by directors of subsidiary, (13) observance of formal corporate legal requirements, (14) contracts between subsidiary and parent, and (15) fraud or injustice to third parties.

Headnote: In a parent-subsidiary relationship, the parent corporation is ordinarily not liable for tortious acts of the subsidiary corporation, unless there is evidence to support a finding which would pierce the corporate veil.

Title: Townley v. Emerson Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Monroe County, New York.
Headnote: On occasion, courts will disregard the separate legal personality of corporation, and assign liability to its owners where necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity; however, such liability can never be predicated solely upon fact of a parent corporation's ownership of a controlling interest in shares of its subsidiary, and at the very least, there must be direct intervention by parent in management of subsidiary to such an extent that subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors, and officers are completely ignored.

Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced (1) to achieve equity, even absent fraud, where officers and employees of parent corporation exercise control over daily operations of subsidiary corporation and act as true prime movers behind subsidiary's actions, and/or (2) where parent corporation conducts business through subsidiary which exists solely to serve parent.

Title: F.D.I.C. v. Refco Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, factors that courts apply in deciding whether to disregard the separate nature of corporation and corporate subsidiary, not all of which must be present for corporate veil to be pierced, are: (1) whether parent corporation owns all or a majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) whether parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) whether parent finances subsidiary; (4) whether parent subscribes to all the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) whether subsidiary' is referred to as such in papers of parent corporation and in statements of its officers; (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary fail to act independently in interests of subsidiary; and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are disregarded.

Title: In re Audre, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Absent illegitimate purposes, the separate existence of subsidiary corporation will be recognized, unless: (a) the business transactions, property, employees, bank and other accounts and records of corporation and subsidiary are intermingled; (b) formalities of separate corporate procedures for each corporation are not observed; (c) subsidiary corporation is inadequately financed as separate unit from the point of view of meeting its normal obligations; (d) respective enterprises are not held out to the public as separate enterprises; and (e) policies of subsidiary corporation are not directed to its own interests primarily, but rather to those of parent corporation.

Headnote: Under South Dakota law, factors which trial court considers in deciding whether to hold parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary include: whether parent owns most of capital stock of subsidiary; whether parent and subsidiary corporations have common directors or officers; whether parent finances subsidiary; whether parents subscribed to all the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise caused its incorporation; whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; whether parent pays salaries and other expenses and losses of subsidiary; whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; whether subsidiary is described in papers of parent corporation or in statements of its officers as mere department or division of parent; whether parent uses property of subsidiary as its own; whether directors or executives of subsidiary act independently in interest of subsidiary or simply take their orders from parent; and whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary are observed.

Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil it must be shown that parent's disregard of corporate entity made subsidiary mere instrumentality for transaction of parent's affairs, that there was such unity of interest in ownership that separate personalities of subsidiary and parent no longer exist, and that to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.

Headnote: Standing alone, lawful uses of subsidiary corporation by its parent corporation cannot support claim against parent under theory of apparent agency or joint venturer; such claims must rest upon factors other than those which law contemplates and approves.

Title: In re Manhattan Woods Golf Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, court may not pierce corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for acts of subsidiary unless parent corporation has exercised such control over subsidiary that subsidiary has become mere instrumentality of parent, which is the real actor, unless such control has been used to commit fraud or other wrong, and unless fraud or wrong results in unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.

Title: Powers v. Fox Television Stations, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors relevant in determining whether subsidiary is merely "alter ego" of its parents include (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate records, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of corporations as if it were its own. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1332(c)(1).

Title: Seasword v. Hilti, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities will be respected, and law presumes that absent some abuse of corporate form, parent and subsidiary corporations are separate and distinct entities; presumption, often referred to as "corporate veil," may be pierced only where otherwise separate corporate existence has been used to subvert justice or cause result that is contrary to some other clearly overriding public policy, and subsidiary must become mere instrumentality of parent before its separate corporate existence will be disregarded.

Headnote: In essence, alter ego theory merely allows plaintiff to hold shareholder or parent corporation liable under Texas law for actions of subsidiary corporation, but this mechanism establishes liability in only one direction, and, while parent corporation can be held liable for acts of subsidiary corporation under alter ego theory, subsidiary corporation is not liable for acts of parent or shareholder merely on basis of alter ego.

Title: In re Keene Corp.

Headnote: Under doctrine of piercing corporate veil, also known as alter ego liability, creditor can sue parent or shareholder of his debtor if he can establish that parent or shareholder controls or dominates the debtor, the control or domination has been used to commit or perpetuate fraud or wrong, and creditor has suffered injury or loss.

Headnote: A corporation's separate and distinct entity will be disregarded, and corporate veil pierced, where subsidiary is so organized and controlled, and its affairs so conducted by a parent, that observance of fiction of separate identities would sanction a fraud or promote injustice under the circumstances.

Title: Paglin v. Saztec Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Circumstances to consider under Missouri law in determining whether parent corporation "controls" subsidiary, for purposes of alter ego liability, are that parent owns all or most of subsidiary's capital stock; parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; parent finances subsidiary; parent subscribes to all of subsidiary's capital stock or otherwise causes its incorporation; subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary; subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; in papers of parent or statements of its officers, subsidiary is described as department, division of parent, or its business or financial responsibility is referred to as parent's own; parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; subsidiary's directors or executives do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take their orders from parent and the latter's interest; and formal legal requirements of subsidiary are not observed.

Title: Matter of Typhoon Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E. D. New York.
Headnote: Under the "alter ego theory," corporate veil may be pierced if the subsidiary does not trade under its own name, the subsidiary does not have separate assets, creditors or obligations, the subsidiary has not held itself out to the general public and trade creditors as a business separate and distinct from parent, there has been a commingling of assets between subsidiary and parent, the subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, the parent pays the debts of the subsidiary, the subsidiary's source of business is dependent upon that of its parent, and the subsidiary disregards its separate and independent corporate entity.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Facts that nonresident parent corporation received monthly financial reports from subsidiary and consulted with its officers, that parent provided financial support, that employment contracts of officers of subsidiary required them to be available in an advisory capacity to parent, that two of parent's staff members were on subsidiary's board of directors, that parent's employee stock purchase plan was available to employees of subsidiary, and that subsidiary was sold as an unprofitable investment did not warrant application of alter ego doctrine for jurisdiction over parent which, unlike subsidiary, had not engaged in any business transactions in the state, where total participation of parent in affairs of subsidiary did not amount to a domination of day to day business decisions of subsidiary. Title: Brown v. Standard Casket Mfg. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama
Headnote: Generally, corporation's ownership of controlling stock of another corporation does not destroy the latter corporation's identity as a distinct legal entity, and the former corporation is not liable for torts of the latter corporation unless separate corporate existence is mere sham, or is an instrument for concealing the truth or perpetrating fraud, or the latter corporation is an instrumentality or adjunct of the former corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1053 Parent and subsidiary corporations in general >
Title: Hollywood Cleaning & Pressing Co. v. Hollywood Laundry Service
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: Parent corporation's ownership of all stock of another corporation will not warrant disregarding separate corporate entity unless unity of interest has destroyed individuality of each corporation, and observance of separate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
